content: They’ve always done my sonograms in tiny windowless rooms—warm and humid rooms with overhead lights they can dim so I don’t have to close my eyes when lying back. I think they save the bigger rooms for women who have someone with them. Technicians always speak in soothing tones, their practiced expressionless faces turned slightly away, focused on my insides rather than my external presentation. Not that I cry or anything — maybe a little sharp intake of breath as they push down on the bladder they make me keep full — because I’ve practiced my own expressionlessness, too.It’s easier to wear dresses when you go, but no one tells you that before your first one. With a dress, there’s no wriggling my pants down and my shirt up while trying not to rip the paper on the table, no tucking the zipper of my jeans under the folds of my burgeoning belly without it scratching. With a dress, I can just pull it up over my waist (like that last time we had sex, when we couldn’t wait to undress, mutually desperate for that moment of ecstatic physical connection) and pull my stockings or underwear down, and, when it’s done (again, like that last time we fucked), wipe away the goo that’s left over and get on my way.My last one was different, of course. Hung over after two days of post-breakup binge drinking, exhaling mezcal fumes with every breath that the technician must’ve smelled, it took three attempts to get my dehydrated husk of a 40-year-old body to have a full enough bladder for the machine to look inside my uterus. I was glad there wasn’t an empty chair next to the table for a once-loved one to sit in, and when she pressed down and I inhaled sharply as my insides appeared in black-and-white on the just-visible screen, it was less because of how badly I had to pee and more because I heard his voice in my head, telling me how he hadn’t wanted more children but that he thought he should have one with me.I closed my eyes and counted to 10 as she clicked and typed, and clicked and typed, forcing the muscles under my eyes to relax and the ones under my throat to contract, not crying.“This one is the most important one,” she murmured. “I know it’s uncomfortable, but because it’s at the base of your uterus, we can’t really see farther up once we do the transvaginal.”“I know,” I said. “Do what you need to do.”She clicked and typed, and clicked and typed, and I half-stared at the screen, hands resting just under my breasts, trying not to imagine what it would be like to look at it with happy anticipation instead of dread.Her clicking slowed, and her movements became more tentative. “How many did you say there were?” she said, looking over at her computer for my last sonogram as reference.“Two,” I said, “One at the bottom and one nearer to the top.”She looked, and moved the wand, and looked and moved the wand, and pursed her lips.“I think I see a third,” she said.My body, you see, has never produced a baby, but sometime in the past few years, it became a producer of prodigious uterine fibroid tumors. And two days after my latest breakup, in January, I found out that it had produced a third.“They feed on your blood,” the technician said, half to herself, pressing down and looking at the screen again. “Little bloodsuckers.”Elizabeth Stewart, MD, of Mayo Clinic, literally wrote the book on uterine fibroids and sees and treats patients in addition to her research. “Almost 70 percent of white women and over 80 percent of black women will be diagnosed with fibroids within their lifetime,” she said to me over the phone in February 2018 with just the slightest hint of a comforting Minnesota accent. And yet, Stewart notes that the research on them, let alone funding for such research, is still pretty thin.“If you look at cancer therapy,” Stewart said, “there’s a lot of research that’s been done to say if I have breast cancer that’s this stage, and this grade, and that these molecules expressed on the tumor, then I’m better off doing a lumpectomy and radiation. Whereas if I have something else, I may be better off doing a mastectomy or a lumpectomy and chemotherapy. We don’t have that kind of research to tell us what to do for fibroids, so it’s a hard field to navigate.”There are, however, a variety of treatments: hormones to mitigate the major symptoms of fibroids, which include pain and prolonged bleeding (though only treatments that block the production of estrogen and progesterone and thus simulate menopause actually shrink the growths), and a variety of surgical and nonsurgical interventions to remove them, like myomectomy (in which individual fibroids are removed), uterine artery embolization (which cuts off some of the blood flow to the uterus and causes the fibroids to shrink), endometrial ablation (in which the uterine lining is eliminated), or MRI-guided focused ultrasound surgery (in which the fibroids are destroyed with sound waves).But the most common surgical treatment, even in 2018, is hysterectomy: 75 percent of women who opt for or require some sort treatment for fibroids end up having their uteruses — and, in some cases, their ovaries and cervixes — removed.Stewart doesn’t believe that all of these hysterectomies are completely necessary. “Many more women could have alternatives to hysterectomy,” she said. “Sometimes their doctor tells them about it, but says, ‘Well, but you know, if you have a hysterectomy, then you’re over and done with,’ or says, ‘I haven’t seen good results with these.’”She added, “Educating yourself about the options is a critical step before you seek treatment.”Fibroids, physicians like Stewart say, run in families, but hysterectomies already ran in mine, so it’s hard to say if it’s true in my case. Though we can talk about explosive diarrhea at the dinner table in my family, we don’t tend to wax nostalgic about which reproductive system disorder caused the surgeons to cut us open and take our organs out.Stewart sees variations on that silence a lot. “This is one of the issues, since fibroids can run in families,” she told me. “If your mother’s periods last 10 days a month, or your sisters all have eight to 10 days of bleeding, when you say, ‘Gee, you know, am I supposed to be living like this?’ They go, ‘Yeah, that’s all you can do.’”The bleeding is, in Stewart’s experience, what finally drives many of her patients to see doctors, whether because of anemia or sheer, embarrassing, life-disrupting volume. Others go because the pain gets so bad from the size or number of fibroids, or from the way they press on the patient’s bladder and bowels, or from how they intensify period cramps that it convinces them something’s just not right.Still others go to the doctor because their fibroids sat quietly, maybe even relatively painlessly, until the women carrying and feeding them wanted to get pregnant or tried and failed to carry a pregnancy to term. Infertility isn’t just the result of the most common treatment for fibroids; it can also be one of the symptoms — which is ironic, because any pregnancy carried to term reduces your risk of future fibroids.It’s almost as if, having never gestated a baby, your uterus just wants to produce something.At least for now, a hysterectomy isn’t on the table for me; doctors tend to be loath to sterilize white women who have yet to fulfill their biological destiny. Not that it would matter, though, because the surgeon I saw last year said that even on the off chance any sperm could swim up and around the large fibroid at the base of my uterus and worm its way to the center of a healthy, 40-year-old egg in one of my Fallopian tubes, the likelihood that a zygote could find any spare plot of uterine wall to call its own amid the masses was small. And even if life really did win out, the surge in hormones would cause the fibroids grow even more rapidly, suffocating the zygote and probably causing a miscarriage.Little bloodsuckers.I was diagnosed in 2012, not because I was bleeding that much (I told myself) or my periods hurt that much (I told myself), but because my doctor felt something amiss during a pelvic exam just before my 35th birthday. The first question she asked when we had the first set of sonogram results in hand, and then kept asking me every year, is whether I was planning on having children.What she was really asking (what she never said she was really asking) is how long I’d be willing to put up with it — the searing pain of my intensifying period cramps, the way I’d start spurting blood while changing a tampon, the ruined sheets and sofa cushions and jeans and underwear like I was 12 all over again, the potential anemia, and, of course, the gentle swelling of my lower belly that no sit-ups can tame as my uterus swelled with growths — on the off chance that, after some sort of probably surgical intervention, I might be able to conceive and carry to term a baby that’s more than a faceless uterine vampire.She didn’t really believe me when I said no.Or maybe I didn’t believe myself.I was 31 before I’d ever really considered even the idea of having children. I’d been in long-term relationships. I had a friend who swore her biological clock was literally, audibly ticking, and I suggested, because I’m an asshole, that she wasn’t Captain Hook. I’d held babies and smelled their little baby heads and felt that moment of biologically induced peace wash over me. But there was never any ovarian twinge or gripping need or rushing urge to incubate one of my own in my then-pristine uterus.Every time somebody asked if I wanted to have children — and in my twenties, it wasn’t the sort of question anyone asked until we were already fairly involved — I just said that I didn’t, not really.Dave, however, made it clear early in our relationship, the first of my thirties, that kids were something he desperately wanted to have. “I don’t want to be an old father, Megan,” he’d say as we curled up in bed, and I’d look at the creases at the corners his eyes and the couple of gray hairs he hadn’t mentioned noticing, and I’d smile. And as we tumbled around each other that summer and into the fall of 2009 in a haze of oxytocin and affection and certainty about our future together, I thought about what it would be like to look into his dark-brown eyes over the head of a curly-haired, giggling mini-him and thought, “Oh, maybe I do want that, with him.”Five months later — four months after our breakup — he dropped me an email to let me know his new girlfriend was pregnant. It was over Christmas; my younger sister was halfway through her first pregnancy and bitching about her sciatica, lumbering around uncomfortably and keeping anyone from giving her soon-to-be firstborn a nickname that might stick.I buried that moment of desire for children with all the rest of the hope I’d felt for us, focusing my attention instead on the stoner man-child with whom I’d taken to sharing a never-made bed. He swore he didn’t want children; I generally think teenagers, emotional or otherwise, don’t really make the best parents, so we were on the same page. He and his now-wife had a baby within a year of their wedding, several years after we broke up.The question of whether I wanted kids kept coming up throughout my thirties, however, on every second date, in every longer-term relationship. There’s something about dating at that age, maybe, when everyone feels like they’re running out of time or really wants to make sure that you don’t feel like you’re running out of time. But like Nancy Reagan taught us to, I just said no.In a way, dating and having my semiannual fibroid assessment weren’t that different: a near-stranger, having had their face and hands buried in my crotch, asks with a concerned face if I’m thinking about having kids in the near future, and I reassure whomever that I’m not.When I was diagnosed, saying I did not want kids was easy: I was about to embark on my first-ever cohabitation adventure with a man who also did not want kids, and I was happy with what we were building. Plus, the fibroid — I named it Frank — wasn’t that big or that bad, and my doctor suggested we just monitor it and see what happened.And so we monitored. I’d maneuver myself onto an exam table every six months, make a little small talk, reassure the technician I knew she was looking for a fibroid so she didn’t have to practice her blank face. My periods got heavier and heavier. I started buying giant bottles of hydrogen peroxide to get stains out of the sheets, my jeans, my nice underwear, the cushions of the cerulean sofa that my mom bought us as a housewarming gift. I woke up in the middle of the night once, my uterus contracting around something that felt hard and immobile, that felt like it stayed still while I twisted my insides around it, moaning in pain, and, as he snored next to me, spent half an hour agony-panting with the nurse on my health insurance’s doctor line trying to figure out if I should go to the ER. She sent me a keychain afterward; my doctor gave me a prescription pain medication.I bought black underwear, changed the kind of tampons I used, scrubbed blood spots off the bathroom floor, refilled my prescription pain pills. My friend and former boss Anna Holmes, who was diagnosed around the same time as me with a much more serious case (African American women, already more likely to have fibroids than white women, are also more likely to have more and/or larger fibroids at younger ages) had hers removed and sent me a picture, taken by the surgeon, of a plastic Tupperware bin full of veiny Silly Putty–colored masses resting on a surgical drape. It was gross and amazing and, it turns out, is still in the archives of my phone.Then, in 2016, I found out that Frank had grown bigger than my doctor was comfortable with.“I think we should talk about your options,” she said in our meeting after my first sonogram that year.“It had been a long journey with this uterus of mine,” author and professor Melissa Harris-Perry told me on the phone, laughing a little. “We’d done all kinds of things together, and ultimately parted ways.”In 2008, Harris-Perry wrote an essay about having fibroids and choosing to have a hysterectomy at 34; when Anna told me about her diagnosis, I emailed it to her. It has stuck with me in part because Harris-Perry described being at work — on air, as a political analyst for CNN — and having to deal with the bleeding. “I was losing so much blood that I sat on set and sent a text to my best friend: ‘If u dont c me after commercial call 911. I might pass out in ladies room.’”I wasn’t sure what I feared more: death by menstruation (the whole point is that men are supposed to mistrust something that bleeds three to five days a month but doesn’t die, after all) or the idea that you could be a grown woman and still not have your goddamn period under control, bleeding all over yourself and everything else in a public place like it was seventh grade all over again. Of course, it had already happened to me, even before I read her piece: I was at a magazine party when blood started seeping down my legs, trapped by my pantyhose, and I tried to wind my way through the crowd to the bathroom when I was waylaid by someone important. I smiled politely in interminable conversation as I felt the wet, warm blood work itself lower and lower on my thighs toward the hem of my skirt, my panic rising.For Harris-Perry, though, the embarrassment was less keen than the real fear that she might die of the related anemia. She got the call while at Disney World with her then six-year-old daughter: “My doctor said to me, ‘You need to find your way to an emergency room or a physician. You need to get iron on board.’ And I remember saying to her, ‘Listen lady, I’m fat. You ever seen a fat girl die of anemia?’” she said, with another laugh.“But,” Harris-Perry continued, “I remember her using the words ‘life-threatening.’ Now, I’m standing alone as single parent, and in that moment — like, when I think about fear, that is the thing that makes it not like the 13-year-old’s moment of just general embarrassment — I really thought about the fact that my life was in danger. And, as a single parent, that was just not…,” she trailed off, voice starting to break. “I mean, it was devastating.”Like mine, Harris-Perry’s doctor wanted to figure out if she was planning on having more children soon. “It was one of those really irritating things,” she said about the focus on her future fertility. “I’m a person, standing over here bleeding to death all of the time, and so whether or not I’m gonna have a child might be less important than this. Because, actually, I’m never gonna be able to go on another date if I’m bleeding all the time. So then I won’t be having any fucking kids,” she added.Her fibroid took a toll beyond the unmanageable periods and anemia, too. “I felt older then than I do now, 10 years later,” Harris-Perry said, “because I carried weight, because I was again really unable to exercise in the ways that I wanted, and so my body felt creaky and painful all the time. I wanted it to be over. I just couldn’t imagine continuing to manage it. It was so depressing.”And so Harris-Perry, who already had a daughter, opted for a hysterectomy — albeit one that would preserve her cervix and ovaries, which she says helped make her decision easier. “We talk a lot about keeping your ovaries for the hormonal purposes,” she said. “But even though I wasn’t dating, I did expect to have penetrative sex again with a man at some point again in my life, hopefully not that far off. And I didn’t want to lose my cervix in part because it was part of my sexual pleasure, and often that of my partner’s.”“What did matter to me was less the question of fertility, but that I had a lot of my womanhood, identity, and sexual pleasure tied up in the surgery,” Harris-Perry continued. “And the fact that there were options that preserved those things while allowing me to know I didn’t have to deal with the fibroids anymore and all the side effects of that was important to me.”Still, she told me, even though a hysterectomy was the right decision for her, she couldn’t stop the what-ifs. “You regret any choice you make about fertility,” Harris-Perry told me. “You regret your children, you know. You regret your abortions. Any choice you make, you will have moments when you regret it.”But there was another level of emotion for Harris-Perry in choosing a hysterectomy that I won’t experience, if and when my time comes. “I did feel some guilt about making the choice, because I read, and knew, and maybe even reported that black women are so much more likely to get hysterectomies and that it also happens because they are pressured,” she said. “And I think it took me a minute to make the decision because I almost felt like I shouldn’t do it, because so many other people didn’t have a choice or had experienced involuntary sterilization in our history.”“It was a specific angst about how Fannie Loe Hamer didn’t get to make this choice, and my grandmamas didn’t get to make this choice,” Harris-Perry added. “And here I could preserve my uterus and I’m not, and is it like not voting? Is it this terrible thing I’m doing to my foremothers?”Having an African American woman gynecologist helped, she told me: Harris-Perry was able to talk through her concerns, her options, and her potential outcomes and feel comfortable about the decision she made — in part because any option that might have preserved her fertility came with a risk that the fibroids would recur.“It’s the oddest thing,” Harris-Perry explained, “but that hysterectomy is probably the reason I ended up ultimately with a second child.” She and her now-husband, James Perry, added a daughter to their family in 2014, after using IVF and surrogacy. “I really was in such a state, physically and emotionally, that I probably wasn’t able to date just because I was constantly managing this physical thing — at work, in my mind, recreationally.”“It was always the thing I was thinking about,” she added. “And so there wouldn’t have been any space for relationship-making with someone new.”Fibroid Frank had grown to the size of a fetus at the end of its first trimester by the time my gynecologist wanted to talk through my realistic options — including whether 38-year-old me was in the market to aim for a now-geriatric pregnancy.“Are you and your partner planning on having children?” my gynecologist asked me in her cozy file-and-uterus-model-filled office. Something about the way I set my mouth must’ve betrayed me. The cohabitation thing we’d started together, filled with hope nearly four years before, was on the skids, and the first thought that popped into my head was that it’d be hard to get pregnant, even if we wanted to, if we weren’t really having sex.She leaned over and said, kindly, “You know, you don’t have to make that decision today, but you’re going to have to make it soon, because it’s only going to get harder from here.” My eyes started to get watery, not because (as she thought) I was contemplating a life without children, but because I knew he and I would have to make a decision soon, and that it would get harder, and that it wouldn’t be about my uterus.My gynecologist sent me out for a round of different tests — for anemia, of course, as well as an anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) test, which is an indicator of egg health and, some studies have shown, time to menopause. “Maybe you’ll have early menopause,” she said, almost cheerfully. “I went through menopause very young. There’s no point in worrying about this if you’re close to menopause.”I wasn’t sure as I left her office with an order in hand what would be worse: possibly ending a long-term relationship with a vicious, biting fibroid lodged in my uterus that might require major surgery or ending it and immediately getting to enjoy menopause.“Deciding which alternative to hysterectomy is right for which woman is a relatively complex process,” Dr. Stewart explained to me on the phone this February. “You have to take into account her age, and the size of her fibroids, and what symptoms she’s having, and where the fibroids are.”“I think that the most interesting fact about hysterectomy is the fact that only 10 percent of hysterectomies are done for any kind of cancer,” she added. “Fibroids, abnormal bleeding, endometriosis, pelvic prolapse, those kinds of conditions where there are other alternatives that can be tried, account for 90 percent of the surgeries.”Stewart continued, “Most hysterectomies do have alternatives. They may not all be the optimal treatment, but I think women who are presented with choices of hysterectomy or nothing when the problem is fibroids should be a little bit suspicious.”I saw my doctor for a follow-up appointment a few weeks after my blood tests: The AMH test strongly suggested that, like the rest of the women to whom I bear more than a passing physical resemblance, I had a solid decade to go before my body would cut off either Frank’s or my supply of sweet, sweet estrogen. She said we needed to have a more serious discussion after my next sonogram, depending on how much larger my fibroid had gotten.I skipped my next sonogram.I didn’t skip it skip it, I told myself: My job ended, my relationship ended, my health insurance for my new job hadn’t started, my insurance started but then my new job ended in layoffs, my grandfather died, and finally the order for the sonogram got stolen with the rest of my wallet at a wine bar when a girlfriend was trying to cheer me up.I started dating again, the merry-go-round of telling the same stories about myself and asking the same questions about various dudes until we’d gotten tipsy enough to see if it was worth kissing one another. I got a new job and sat at my desk the second week, jaw clenched as Frank roared, trying to assert his independence from my otherwise functional uterus; I was fully prepared to vomit from the pain into my desk trash can. I finally went home in the middle of the day as the nausea eased, shuffling toward the subway like an elderly woman, trying to stay upright, and curled up in bed alone with a heating pad to comfort Frank.I called my doctor, asked to replace the order that had been in my stolen wallet, and made the sonogram appointment. Then I had dinner with Dave.The truth is that, after Dave, I never really said no when someone asked me if I wanted kids — the second time someone asked, anyway. I’d say, “I’ve never wanted children in a vacuum. It seems like something I either want or don’t want in the context of a relationship,” and I just didn’t mention that I’d only ever found the one context in which I wanted them. (That’s something you tell your therapist, not your gynecologist.) It felt — it feels — like something I would need to do with someone I loved more than I had ever loved anyone, someone I trusted wouldn’t leave, someone who could, with me, give a child of mine what I had growing up and maybe more: a two-parent, happy family…or else something I’m not really keen to do at all.But I knew the ultrasound would show Frank had gotten larger; I knew that whatever decision we made about surgery would ultimately depend on whether I wanted to remain fertile; I knew I wasn’t going to be able to just tell myself children just hadn’t worked out for me if I paid a doctor to render me infertile before my time. And I guess a little part of me thought Dave would have part of the answer to the question no one believed my answer to.He didn’t, but he did have the money to pay for his half of two bottles of wine and the kindness to watch me drunkenly sob my way through telling him I didn’t know if I wanted to be infertile, even if it was ultimately less bloody and painful, when I had wanted kids for that brief period with him, before he went and had them with somebody else. And he looked at me with some sort of sadness and what I tell myself wasn’t pity, hugged me, and then he went home to his two curly-haired, brown-eyed kids.I slept off the hangover.Two days later, I lay back in another windowless room, pulled my sundress up to display my belly for another expressionless technician, and went to work late with the sneaking suspicion I’d missed a spot of goo.In August, I met with a surgeon to review my results. Where there had been one fibroid, he told me, there were two and there would likely be more. He asked me if I wanted to have children.And he told me that in all likelihood, without surgery, I was probably functionally infertile now.I started seeing my most recent ex a couple weeks later: We swiped right, exchanged messages, switched to text, met for dinner. It clicked right away: He changed his work schedule to accommodate our seeing one another. We exchanged text messages from morning until night on the days we didn’t. The conversation about whether we wanted children happened early, as they always do when you’re a woman near 40, and I said I’d never really had the urge to have kids, and he said he didn’t want more than the one he already had.We were making plans to go to Italy for my 40th birthday, and he was daydreaming about where we’d be in six months, given as close as we’d gotten in two, when in the middle of our rapid-fire morning text exchange, he suddenly asked me again if I wanted kids.So I told him the whole truth: I had fibroids, and without major surgery, I was unlikely to be able to conceive. And with major surgery, I’d probably be resigning myself to a C-section if I did choose to have them.Then I texted: “You said you didn’t want any more, though. Still true?”“Yep,” he replied. “Unless we decide otherwise.”“Your brain deserves replicating.”I don’t know why I took it so seriously, except that I don’t say shit like that if I don’t really, really mean it. Plus, he’d bring up having kids every so often, out of the blue, like it had been on his mind — that he hadn’t really thought about having another kid until being with me, how different parenting would be with me than it had been with his ex if he and I had a baby — and as we settled into what felt like a happy, functional routine, I thought about my surgical options, and my next sonogram, and what to say about whether I wanted kids this next time when the doctor asked.Could it really be with a two-time divorcé with a kid of his own, the kind of man who had a framed picture of his son’s nine-year-old sonogram on his dresser in a frame that read “Love at first sight”?It wasn’t, of course. His text messages slowed, I withdrew, he withdrew, and one night, two days before my last sonogram, we held each other in my bed as he stroked my hair and said that he wasn’t sure that he could fall in love with anyone again, and I sighed and stopped crying and said, “Okay,” and we said our goodbyes.That’s the problem with contextual desires — the context changes.I’ve named the new fibroid Malcolm (because he’s in the middle); I can tell he’s going to be a sonofabitch. And I’ll go back to the doctor soon, and she’ll ask me if I want children, and maybe I’ll tell her the truth this time: that I’ve never felt that socio-biological urge to gestate and raise a baby at any cost, but every once in a blue moon, I have the inkling of a desire to build a family, someday, of something more than anthropomorphized uterine bloodsuckers.Or maybe I’ll just say no. Because it’s easier.Illustration: Audrey Lee. Creative art direction: Anagraph.

They’ve always done my sonograms in tiny windowless rooms—warm and humid rooms with overhead lights they can dim so I don’t have to close my eyes when lying back. I think they save the bigger rooms for women who have someone with them. Technicians always speak in soothing tones, their practiced expressionless faces turned slightly away, focused on my insides rather than my external presentation. Not that I cry or anything — maybe a little sharp intake of breath as they push down on the bladder they make me keep full — because I’ve practiced my own expressionlessness, too.

It’s easier to wear dresses when you go, but no one tells you that before your first one. With a dress, there’s no wriggling my pants down and my shirt up while trying not to rip the paper on the table, no tucking the zipper of my jeans under the folds of my burgeoning belly without it scratching. With a dress, I can just pull it up over my waist (like that last time we had sex, when we couldn’t wait to undress, mutually desperate for that moment of ecstatic physical connection) and pull my stockings or underwear down, and, when it’s done (again, like that last time we fucked), wipe away the goo that’s left over and get on my way.

My last one was different, of course. Hung over after two days of post-breakup binge drinking, exhaling mezcal fumes with every breath that the technician must’ve smelled, it took three attempts to get my dehydrated husk of a 40-year-old body to have a full enough bladder for the machine to look inside my uterus. I was glad there wasn’t an empty chair next to the table for a once-loved one to sit in, and when she pressed down and I inhaled sharply as my insides appeared in black-and-white on the just-visible screen, it was less because of how badly I had to pee and more because I heard his voice in my head, telling me how he hadn’t wanted more children but that he thought he should have one with me.

I closed my eyes and counted to 10 as she clicked and typed, and clicked and typed, forcing the muscles under my eyes to relax and the ones under my throat to contract, not crying.

“This one is the most important one,” she murmured. “I know it’s uncomfortable, but because it’s at the base of your uterus, we can’t really see farther up once we do the transvaginal.”

“I know,” I said. “Do what you need to do.”

She clicked and typed, and clicked and typed, and I half-stared at the screen, hands resting just under my breasts, trying not to imagine what it would be like to look at it with happy anticipation instead of dread.

Her clicking slowed, and her movements became more tentative. “How many did you say there were?” she said, looking over at her computer for my last sonogram as reference.

“Two,” I said, “One at the bottom and one nearer to the top.”

She looked, and moved the wand, and looked and moved the wand, and pursed her lips.

“I think I see a third,” she said.

My body, you see, has never produced a baby, but sometime in the past few years, it became a producer of prodigious uterine fibroid tumors. And two days after my latest breakup, in January, I found out that it had produced a third.

“They feed on your blood,” the technician said, half to herself, pressing down and looking at the screen again. “Little bloodsuckers.”

Elizabeth Stewart, MD, of Mayo Clinic, literally wrote the book on uterine fibroids and sees and treats patients in addition to her research. “Almost 70 percent of white women and over 80 percent of black women will be diagnosed with fibroids within their lifetime,” she said to me over the phone in February 2018 with just the slightest hint of a comforting Minnesota accent. And yet, Stewart notes that the research on them, let alone funding for such research, is still pretty thin.

“If you look at cancer therapy,” Stewart said, “there’s a lot of research that’s been done to say if I have breast cancer that’s this stage, and this grade, and that these molecules expressed on the tumor, then I’m better off doing a lumpectomy and radiation. Whereas if I have something else, I may be better off doing a mastectomy or a lumpectomy and chemotherapy. We don’t have that kind of research to tell us what to do for fibroids, so it’s a hard field to navigate.”

There are, however, a variety of treatments: hormones to mitigate the major symptoms of fibroids, which include pain and prolonged bleeding (though only treatments that block the production of estrogen and progesterone and thus simulate menopause actually shrink the growths), and a variety of surgical and nonsurgical interventions to remove them, like myomectomy (in which individual fibroids are removed), uterine artery embolization (which cuts off some of the blood flow to the uterus and causes the fibroids to shrink), endometrial ablation (in which the uterine lining is eliminated), or MRI-guided focused ultrasound surgery (in which the fibroids are destroyed with sound waves).

But the most common surgical treatment, even in 2018, is hysterectomy: 75 percent of women who opt for or require some sort treatment for fibroids end up having their uteruses — and, in some cases, their ovaries and cervixes — removed.

Stewart doesn’t believe that all of these hysterectomies are completely necessary. “Many more women could have alternatives to hysterectomy,” she said. “Sometimes their doctor tells them about it, but says, ‘Well, but you know, if you have a hysterectomy, then you’re over and done with,’ or says, ‘I haven’t seen good results with these.’”

She added, “Educating yourself about the options is a critical step before you seek treatment.”

Fibroids, physicians like Stewart say, run in families, but hysterectomies already ran in mine, so it’s hard to say if it’s true in my case. Though we can talk about explosive diarrhea at the dinner table in my family, we don’t tend to wax nostalgic about which reproductive system disorder caused the surgeons to cut us open and take our organs out.

Stewart sees variations on that silence a lot. “This is one of the issues, since fibroids can run in families,” she told me. “If your mother’s periods last 10 days a month, or your sisters all have eight to 10 days of bleeding, when you say, ‘Gee, you know, am I supposed to be living like this?’ They go, ‘Yeah, that’s all you can do.’”

The bleeding is, in Stewart’s experience, what finally drives many of her patients to see doctors, whether because of anemia or sheer, embarrassing, life-disrupting volume. Others go because the pain gets so bad from the size or number of fibroids, or from the way they press on the patient’s bladder and bowels, or from how they intensify period cramps that it convinces them something’s just not right.

Still others go to the doctor because their fibroids sat quietly, maybe even relatively painlessly, until the women carrying and feeding them wanted to get pregnant or tried and failed to carry a pregnancy to term. Infertility isn’t just the result of the most common treatment for fibroids; it can also be one of the symptoms — which is ironic, because any pregnancy carried to term reduces your risk of future fibroids.

It’s almost as if, having never gestated a baby, your uterus just wants to produce something.

At least for now, a hysterectomy isn’t on the table for me; doctors tend to be loath to sterilize white women who have yet to fulfill their biological destiny. Not that it would matter, though, because the surgeon I saw last year said that even on the off chance any sperm could swim up and around the large fibroid at the base of my uterus and worm its way to the center of a healthy, 40-year-old egg in one of my Fallopian tubes, the likelihood that a zygote could find any spare plot of uterine wall to call its own amid the masses was small. And even if life really did win out, the surge in hormones would cause the fibroids grow even more rapidly, suffocating the zygote and probably causing a miscarriage.

Little bloodsuckers.

I was diagnosed in 2012, not because I was bleeding that much (I told myself) or my periods hurt that much (I told myself), but because my doctor felt something amiss during a pelvic exam just before my 35th birthday. The first question she asked when we had the first set of sonogram results in hand, and then kept asking me every year, is whether I was planning on having children.

What she was really asking (what she never said she was really asking) is how long I’d be willing to put up with it — the searing pain of my intensifying period cramps, the way I’d start spurting blood while changing a tampon, the ruined sheets and sofa cushions and jeans and underwear like I was 12 all over again, the potential anemia, and, of course, the gentle swelling of my lower belly that no sit-ups can tame as my uterus swelled with growths — on the off chance that, after some sort of probably surgical intervention, I might be able to conceive and carry to term a baby that’s more than a faceless uterine vampire.

She didn’t really believe me when I said no.

Or maybe I didn’t believe myself.

I was 31 before I’d ever really considered even the idea of having children. I’d been in long-term relationships. I had a friend who swore her biological clock was literally, audibly ticking, and I suggested, because I’m an asshole, that she wasn’t Captain Hook. I’d held babies and smelled their little baby heads and felt that moment of biologically induced peace wash over me. But there was never any ovarian twinge or gripping need or rushing urge to incubate one of my own in my then-pristine uterus.

Every time somebody asked if I wanted to have children — and in my twenties, it wasn’t the sort of question anyone asked until we were already fairly involved — I just said that I didn’t, not really.

Dave, however, made it clear early in our relationship, the first of my thirties, that kids were something he desperately wanted to have. “I don’t want to be an old father, Megan,” he’d say as we curled up in bed, and I’d look at the creases at the corners his eyes and the couple of gray hairs he hadn’t mentioned noticing, and I’d smile. And as we tumbled around each other that summer and into the fall of 2009 in a haze of oxytocin and affection and certainty about our future together, I thought about what it would be like to look into his dark-brown eyes over the head of a curly-haired, giggling mini-him and thought, “Oh, maybe I do want that, with him.”

Five months later — four months after our breakup — he dropped me an email to let me know his new girlfriend was pregnant. It was over Christmas; my younger sister was halfway through her first pregnancy and bitching about her sciatica, lumbering around uncomfortably and keeping anyone from giving her soon-to-be firstborn a nickname that might stick.

I buried that moment of desire for children with all the rest of the hope I’d felt for us, focusing my attention instead on the stoner man-child with whom I’d taken to sharing a never-made bed. He swore he didn’t want children; I generally think teenagers, emotional or otherwise, don’t really make the best parents, so we were on the same page. He and his now-wife had a baby within a year of their wedding, several years after we broke up.

The question of whether I wanted kids kept coming up throughout my thirties, however, on every second date, in every longer-term relationship. There’s something about dating at that age, maybe, when everyone feels like they’re running out of time or really wants to make sure that you don’t feel like you’re running out of time. But like Nancy Reagan taught us to, I just said no.

In a way, dating and having my semiannual fibroid assessment weren’t that different: a near-stranger, having had their face and hands buried in my crotch, asks with a concerned face if I’m thinking about having kids in the near future, and I reassure whomever that I’m not.

When I was diagnosed, saying I did not want kids was easy: I was about to embark on my first-ever cohabitation adventure with a man who also did not want kids, and I was happy with what we were building. Plus, the fibroid — I named it Frank — wasn’t that big or that bad, and my doctor suggested we just monitor it and see what happened.

And so we monitored. I’d maneuver myself onto an exam table every six months, make a little small talk, reassure the technician I knew she was looking for a fibroid so she didn’t have to practice her blank face. My periods got heavier and heavier. I started buying giant bottles of hydrogen peroxide to get stains out of the sheets, my jeans, my nice underwear, the cushions of the cerulean sofa that my mom bought us as a housewarming gift. I woke up in the middle of the night once, my uterus contracting around something that felt hard and immobile, that felt like it stayed still while I twisted my insides around it, moaning in pain, and, as he snored next to me, spent half an hour agony-panting with the nurse on my health insurance’s doctor line trying to figure out if I should go to the ER. She sent me a keychain afterward; my doctor gave me a prescription pain medication.

I bought black underwear, changed the kind of tampons I used, scrubbed blood spots off the bathroom floor, refilled my prescription pain pills. My friend and former boss Anna Holmes, who was diagnosed around the same time as me with a much more serious case (African American women, already more likely to have fibroids than white women, are also more likely to have more and/or larger fibroids at younger ages) had hers removed and sent me a picture, taken by the surgeon, of a plastic Tupperware bin full of veiny Silly Putty–colored masses resting on a surgical drape. It was gross and amazing and, it turns out, is still in the archives of my phone.

Then, in 2016, I found out that Frank had grown bigger than my doctor was comfortable with.

“I think we should talk about your options,” she said in our meeting after my first sonogram that year.

“It had been a long journey with this uterus of mine,” author and professor Melissa Harris-Perry told me on the phone, laughing a little. “We’d done all kinds of things together, and ultimately parted ways.”

In 2008, Harris-Perry wrote an essay about having fibroids and choosing to have a hysterectomy at 34; when Anna told me about her diagnosis, I emailed it to her. It has stuck with me in part because Harris-Perry described being at work — on air, as a political analyst for CNN — and having to deal with the bleeding. “I was losing so much blood that I sat on set and sent a text to my best friend: ‘If u dont c me after commercial call 911. I might pass out in ladies room.’”

I wasn’t sure what I feared more: death by menstruation (the whole point is that men are supposed to mistrust something that bleeds three to five days a month but doesn’t die, after all) or the idea that you could be a grown woman and still not have your goddamn period under control, bleeding all over yourself and everything else in a public place like it was seventh grade all over again. Of course, it had already happened to me, even before I read her piece: I was at a magazine party when blood started seeping down my legs, trapped by my pantyhose, and I tried to wind my way through the crowd to the bathroom when I was waylaid by someone important. I smiled politely in interminable conversation as I felt the wet, warm blood work itself lower and lower on my thighs toward the hem of my skirt, my panic rising.

For Harris-Perry, though, the embarrassment was less keen than the real fear that she might die of the related anemia. She got the call while at Disney World with her then six-year-old daughter: “My doctor said to me, ‘You need to find your way to an emergency room or a physician. You need to get iron on board.’ And I remember saying to her, ‘Listen lady, I’m fat. You ever seen a fat girl die of anemia?’” she said, with another laugh.

“But,” Harris-Perry continued, “I remember her using the words ‘life-threatening.’ Now, I’m standing alone as single parent, and in that moment — like, when I think about fear, that is the thing that makes it not like the 13-year-old’s moment of just general embarrassment — I really thought about the fact that my life was in danger. And, as a single parent, that was just not…,” she trailed off, voice starting to break. “I mean, it was devastating.”

Like mine, Harris-Perry’s doctor wanted to figure out if she was planning on having more children soon. “It was one of those really irritating things,” she said about the focus on her future fertility. “I’m a person, standing over here bleeding to death all of the time, and so whether or not I’m gonna have a child might be less important than this. Because, actually, I’m never gonna be able to go on another date if I’m bleeding all the time. So then I won’t be having any fucking kids,” she added.

Her fibroid took a toll beyond the unmanageable periods and anemia, too. “I felt older then than I do now, 10 years later,” Harris-Perry said, “because I carried weight, because I was again really unable to exercise in the ways that I wanted, and so my body felt creaky and painful all the time. I wanted it to be over. I just couldn’t imagine continuing to manage it. It was so depressing.”

And so Harris-Perry, who already had a daughter, opted for a hysterectomy — albeit one that would preserve her cervix and ovaries, which she says helped make her decision easier. “We talk a lot about keeping your ovaries for the hormonal purposes,” she said. “But even though I wasn’t dating, I did expect to have penetrative sex again with a man at some point again in my life, hopefully not that far off. And I didn’t want to lose my cervix in part because it was part of my sexual pleasure, and often that of my partner’s.”

“What did matter to me was less the question of fertility, but that I had a lot of my womanhood, identity, and sexual pleasure tied up in the surgery,” Harris-Perry continued. “And the fact that there were options that preserved those things while allowing me to know I didn’t have to deal with the fibroids anymore and all the side effects of that was important to me.”

Still, she told me, even though a hysterectomy was the right decision for her, she couldn’t stop the what-ifs. “You regret any choice you make about fertility,” Harris-Perry told me. “You regret your children, you know. You regret your abortions. Any choice you make, you will have moments when you regret it.”

But there was another level of emotion for Harris-Perry in choosing a hysterectomy that I won’t experience, if and when my time comes. “I did feel some guilt about making the choice, because I read, and knew, and maybe even reported that black women are so much more likely to get hysterectomies and that it also happens because they are pressured,” she said. “And I think it took me a minute to make the decision because I almost felt like I shouldn’t do it, because so many other people didn’t have a choice or had experienced involuntary sterilization in our history.”

“It was a specific angst about how Fannie Loe Hamer didn’t get to make this choice, and my grandmamas didn’t get to make this choice,” Harris-Perry added. “And here I could preserve my uterus and I’m not, and is it like not voting? Is it this terrible thing I’m doing to my foremothers?”

Having an African American woman gynecologist helped, she told me: Harris-Perry was able to talk through her concerns, her options, and her potential outcomes and feel comfortable about the decision she made — in part because any option that might have preserved her fertility came with a risk that the fibroids would recur.

“It’s the oddest thing,” Harris-Perry explained, “but that hysterectomy is probably the reason I ended up ultimately with a second child.” She and her now-husband, James Perry, added a daughter to their family in 2014, after using IVF and surrogacy. “I really was in such a state, physically and emotionally, that I probably wasn’t able to date just because I was constantly managing this physical thing — at work, in my mind, recreationally.”

“It was always the thing I was thinking about,” she added. “And so there wouldn’t have been any space for relationship-making with someone new.”

Fibroid Frank had grown to the size of a fetus at the end of its first trimester by the time my gynecologist wanted to talk through my realistic options — including whether 38-year-old me was in the market to aim for a now-geriatric pregnancy.

“Are you and your partner planning on having children?” my gynecologist asked me in her cozy file-and-uterus-model-filled office. Something about the way I set my mouth must’ve betrayed me. The cohabitation thing we’d started together, filled with hope nearly four years before, was on the skids, and the first thought that popped into my head was that it’d be hard to get pregnant, even if we wanted to, if we weren’t really having sex.

She leaned over and said, kindly, “You know, you don’t have to make that decision today, but you’re going to have to make it soon, because it’s only going to get harder from here.” My eyes started to get watery, not because (as she thought) I was contemplating a life without children, but because I knew he and I would have to make a decision soon, and that it would get harder, and that it wouldn’t be about my uterus.

My gynecologist sent me out for a round of different tests — for anemia, of course, as well as an anti-Müllerian hormone (AMH) test, which is an indicator of egg health and, some studies have shown, time to menopause. “Maybe you’ll have early menopause,” she said, almost cheerfully. “I went through menopause very young. There’s no point in worrying about this if you’re close to menopause.”

I wasn’t sure as I left her office with an order in hand what would be worse: possibly ending a long-term relationship with a vicious, biting fibroid lodged in my uterus that might require major surgery or ending it and immediately getting to enjoy menopause.

“Deciding which alternative to hysterectomy is right for which woman is a relatively complex process,” Dr. Stewart explained to me on the phone this February. “You have to take into account her age, and the size of her fibroids, and what symptoms she’s having, and where the fibroids are.”

“I think that the most interesting fact about hysterectomy is the fact that only 10 percent of hysterectomies are done for any kind of cancer,” she added. “Fibroids, abnormal bleeding, endometriosis, pelvic prolapse, those kinds of conditions where there are other alternatives that can be tried, account for 90 percent of the surgeries.”

Stewart continued, “Most hysterectomies do have alternatives. They may not all be the optimal treatment, but I think women who are presented with choices of hysterectomy or nothing when the problem is fibroids should be a little bit suspicious.”

I saw my doctor for a follow-up appointment a few weeks after my blood tests: The AMH test strongly suggested that, like the rest of the women to whom I bear more than a passing physical resemblance, I had a solid decade to go before my body would cut off either Frank’s or my supply of sweet, sweet estrogen. She said we needed to have a more serious discussion after my next sonogram, depending on how much larger my fibroid had gotten.

I skipped my next sonogram.

I didn’t skip it skip it, I told myself: My job ended, my relationship ended, my health insurance for my new job hadn’t started, my insurance started but then my new job ended in layoffs, my grandfather died, and finally the order for the sonogram got stolen with the rest of my wallet at a wine bar when a girlfriend was trying to cheer me up.

I started dating again, the merry-go-round of telling the same stories about myself and asking the same questions about various dudes until we’d gotten tipsy enough to see if it was worth kissing one another. I got a new job and sat at my desk the second week, jaw clenched as Frank roared, trying to assert his independence from my otherwise functional uterus; I was fully prepared to vomit from the pain into my desk trash can. I finally went home in the middle of the day as the nausea eased, shuffling toward the subway like an elderly woman, trying to stay upright, and curled up in bed alone with a heating pad to comfort Frank.

I called my doctor, asked to replace the order that had been in my stolen wallet, and made the sonogram appointment. Then I had dinner with Dave.

The truth is that, after Dave, I never really said no when someone asked me if I wanted kids — the second time someone asked, anyway. I’d say, “I’ve never wanted children in a vacuum. It seems like something I either want or don’t want in the context of a relationship,” and I just didn’t mention that I’d only ever found the one context in which I wanted them. (That’s something you tell your therapist, not your gynecologist.) It felt — it feels — like something I would need to do with someone I loved more than I had ever loved anyone, someone I trusted wouldn’t leave, someone who could, with me, give a child of mine what I had growing up and maybe more: a two-parent, happy family…or else something I’m not really keen to do at all.

But I knew the ultrasound would show Frank had gotten larger; I knew that whatever decision we made about surgery would ultimately depend on whether I wanted to remain fertile; I knew I wasn’t going to be able to just tell myself children just hadn’t worked out for me if I paid a doctor to render me infertile before my time. And I guess a little part of me thought Dave would have part of the answer to the question no one believed my answer to.

He didn’t, but he did have the money to pay for his half of two bottles of wine and the kindness to watch me drunkenly sob my way through telling him I didn’t know if I wanted to be infertile, even if it was ultimately less bloody and painful, when I had wanted kids for that brief period with him, before he went and had them with somebody else. And he looked at me with some sort of sadness and what I tell myself wasn’t pity, hugged me, and then he went home to his two curly-haired, brown-eyed kids.

I slept off the hangover.

Two days later, I lay back in another windowless room, pulled my sundress up to display my belly for another expressionless technician, and went to work late with the sneaking suspicion I’d missed a spot of goo.

In August, I met with a surgeon to review my results. Where there had been one fibroid, he told me, there were two and there would likely be more. He asked me if I wanted to have children.

And he told me that in all likelihood, without surgery, I was probably functionally infertile now.

I started seeing my most recent ex a couple weeks later: We swiped right, exchanged messages, switched to text, met for dinner. It clicked right away: He changed his work schedule to accommodate our seeing one another. We exchanged text messages from morning until night on the days we didn’t. The conversation about whether we wanted children happened early, as they always do when you’re a woman near 40, and I said I’d never really had the urge to have kids, and he said he didn’t want more than the one he already had.

We were making plans to go to Italy for my 40th birthday, and he was daydreaming about where we’d be in six months, given as close as we’d gotten in two, when in the middle of our rapid-fire morning text exchange, he suddenly asked me again if I wanted kids.

So I told him the whole truth: I had fibroids, and without major surgery, I was unlikely to be able to conceive. And with major surgery, I’d probably be resigning myself to a C-section if I did choose to have them.

Then I texted: “You said you didn’t want any more, though. Still true?”

“Yep,” he replied. “Unless we decide otherwise.”

“Your brain deserves replicating.”

I don’t know why I took it so seriously, except that I don’t say shit like that if I don’t really, really mean it. Plus, he’d bring up having kids every so often, out of the blue, like it had been on his mind — that he hadn’t really thought about having another kid until being with me, how different parenting would be with me than it had been with his ex if he and I had a baby — and as we settled into what felt like a happy, functional routine, I thought about my surgical options, and my next sonogram, and what to say about whether I wanted kids this next time when the doctor asked.

Could it really be with a two-time divorcé with a kid of his own, the kind of man who had a framed picture of his son’s nine-year-old sonogram on his dresser in a frame that read “Love at first sight”?

It wasn’t, of course. His text messages slowed, I withdrew, he withdrew, and one night, two days before my last sonogram, we held each other in my bed as he stroked my hair and said that he wasn’t sure that he could fall in love with anyone again, and I sighed and stopped crying and said, “Okay,” and we said our goodbyes.

That’s the problem with contextual desires — the context changes.

I’ve named the new fibroid Malcolm (because he’s in the middle); I can tell he’s going to be a sonofabitch. And I’ll go back to the doctor soon, and she’ll ask me if I want children, and maybe I’ll tell her the truth this time: that I’ve never felt that socio-biological urge to gestate and raise a baby at any cost, but every once in a blue moon, I have the inkling of a desire to build a family, someday, of something more than anthropomorphized uterine bloodsuckers.

Or maybe I’ll just say no. Because it’s easier.
